DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Futures Skyrocket as Cold Snap Continues
DOC.TEXT: Heating oil futures soared Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as forecasts for more brutally cold weather attracted new buyers to a market that has been climbing with barely a pause for five weeks. On other other commodity markets Monday, precious metals were lower; livestock futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower. Heating oil futures settled .49 cent to 4.24 cents higher with the contract for delivery in January up 4.24 cents at 74.66 cents a gallon, a four-year high. Unleaded gasoline futures finished 1.3 cents to 1.74 cents higher with January at 54.51 cents a gallon; crude oil futures settled 3 cents to $1.12 higher with January at $22.22 a barrel, the highest level since last April. With sub-zero temperature readings boosting domestic demand for heating oil, the entire energy complex has become a weather market. The cold snap that descended on the nation's midsection last week is expected to continue into this weekend, bringing unseasonably frigid temperatures to most of the United States east of the Rockies. ``We've had weather markets in heating oil before but in my lifetime I don't remember a weather market developing this early in the season,'' said James Ritterbusch, a energy market analyst with Carson Petroleum Co., a Chicago-area oil distributor. Weather markets can create huge profits for speculators but they are notoriously treacherous. A hint of a change in the weather pattern can send prices plummeting. The heating oil market began its climb from about 60 cents a gallon in early November amid concerns about tight supplies of heating oil in Europe, which also had an early run-in with Arctic weather. But the European weather has since warmed and river levels there have risen with rain, opening transportation channels that had been problematic. ``A week or two ago, you saw a lot of cargoes from South America being redirected from North America to Europe,'' Ritterbusch said. ``I think some of those ships are now going to be making a U-turn.'' Precious metals futures fell moderately on New York's Commodity Exchange as the dollar showed some strength. Prices opened sharply lower but trimmed their losses by midday, with support stemming from tension over the shooting of a U.S. soldier in Panama. Gold futures settled $2.10 lower across the board with December at $411.80 a troy ounce; silver was 3.9 cents to 4.2 cents lower with December at $5.565 a troy ounce. Pork futures advanced on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on ideas that cold weather would curtail hog marketings. Cattle futures settled mixed in cautious trading ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cattle-on-feed report. The report, which was released after the close, showed 2 percent more cattle on feedlots Dec. 1 than on the same date a year ago compared with market expectations for no change. November feedlot placements were much higher than expected while marketings off of feedlots were only slightly above expectations. Analysts expected the report to prompt some selling of live cattle futures at the opening Tuesday. But the report was perceived as bullish for the cash cattle market and gains there could partially offset selling pressure in the futures markets. Live cattle futures settled .10 cent lower to .35 cent higher with December at 78.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .30 cent higher with January at 84.57 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent to .55 cent higher with December at 53.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .13 cent to .88 cent higher with February at 52.07 cents a pound. Most grain and soybean futures prices fell slightly on the Chicago Board of Trade as new snow insulated the winter wheat crop from the cold and rain brought refief to soybean crops in southern Brazil.
